Answer: I’ve heard that in terms of advanced technology, that it’s usually the Aerospace/Defense industry leading the charge. For example, the defense industry has had 3D printing capabilities since the 1980s, however it’s only recently become mainstream. Another example is GPS. The military had GPS long before it became something that people had in their cars and smartphones. Furthermore, the former head of Lockheed Martin Skunkworks said that they have had technology since the 1970s that people still think is impossible today. This is also true according to my Dad, who was in the Air Force for 22 yeI’ve heard that in terms of advanced technology, that it’s usually the Aerospace/Defense industry leading the charge. For example, the defense industry has had 3D printing capabilities since the 1980s, however it’s only recently become mainstream. Another example is GPS. The military had GPS long before it became something that people had in their cars and smartphones. Furthermore, the former head of Lockheed Martin Skunkworks said that they have had technology since the 1970s that people still think is impossible today. This is also true according to my Dad, who was in the Air Force for 22 years and is now an engineering manager at Boeing. Over the course of his career, he has seen so much bleeding edge technology that he can’t even talk about.If you’re talking about more mainstream technology, then usually it’s a mixture of research laboratories at big companies and at research universities. For example, Bell Labs, formerly owned by AT&T was responsible for the point contact transistor, which one a Nobel Prize, in addition to the Bipolar Junction Transistor (the distinction between the two is not incredibly important for this discussion, but they both are grandfather technologies that allowed for the explosion of computing devices). Also from Bell Labs came the Unix Operating System and the C Programming Language. Unix based operating systems are the inspiration for Linux, and Linux runs on everything from your Set Top Box to the world’s fastest supercomputers. The C programming language is 40 years old and still has applications today, especially in the sphere of embedded software development.ARPAnet, the precursor to the internet was developed at the University of California, Los Angeles in accordance with DARPA, under the direction of Professor Leonard Kleinrock who developed the packet switching protocol while he was doing his Ph. D. UCLA has also produced 7 Nobel Laureates, 17 MacArthur Foundation Fellows, and a Turing Award recipient.

Answer: We are nowhere near it.Nowhere. Not even slightly.An exoskeleton that allows the user to have greater strength for lifting in specific circumstances? Yes. But not a suit. A suit that allows you to breathe? Sure, with GIANT tanks attached to it, for a couple hours.Let’s break down what the suit is and why we can’t have nice things… yet. (and I’m not even going to use the new nano particle suit, just the one from Iron Man I - the very first movie, the basic suit).Fully enclosed suit:We are nowhere near it.Nowhere. Not even slightly.An exoskeleton that allows the user to have greater strength for lifting in specific circumstances? Yes. But not a suit. A suit that allows you to breathe? Sure, with GIANT tanks attached to it, for a couple hours.Let’s break down what the suit is and why we can’t have nice things… yet. (and I’m not even going to use the new nano particle suit, just the one from Iron Man I - the very first movie, the basic suit).Fully enclosed suit:Self contained:Tiny Power Source:Inertia Dampening:Recycling:Strength actuators:Mind Interface:The suit is slow, and easily overcome by attackers if you manipulate it any other way thanRepulsorsAIExotic materials:Actual Holographic displays:As you see any ONE of these inventions would revolutionize its industry and change our lives for the better, but you need ALL of them to replicate his suit. You need the actuators to give it the stretch but the suit would fall apart from stress so you need the exotic materials but then you need to power it so you need a power source that generates enough power in a tiny space that doesn’t kill the wearer with radiation and heat, but you can’t fly unless you have repulsors and then you can’t control it because you don’t have the mind interface, but then you are limited in what you can do unless you have the most advanced and complete and benign AI installed but you can’t do that unless you have the computing power that is insanely powerful in a tiny space and none of that matters because a couple hits from physical attacks would turn your body and brain to jelly from the outside shocks so you need electronic inertial dampeners that would put the Enterprise to shame.And that’s why we can’t have nice things.PS - I’m sure I missed something. :)

Answer: Not meaningfully so, no.There are some historical technologies we can’t quite reproduce, but they’re not terribly significant ones: certain kinds of pottery glazes, dyes, and the like. The best known “lost” technology is probably Greek fire, the famous Medieval incendiary. Generally speaking, these are things where we know the results of the process, but we really don’t know the components which went into it, and we suspect that it relies on the specific properties of limited natural mineral deposits, species of plants, and the like. Oh, and there’s talk that we’ve lost some of the knowledge aNot meaningfully so, no.There are some historical technologies we can’t quite reproduce, but they’re not terribly significant ones: certain kinds of pottery glazes, dyes, and the like. The best known “lost” technology is probably Greek fire, the famous Medieval incendiary. Generally speaking, these are things where we know the results of the process, but we really don’t know the components which went into it, and we suspect that it relies on the specific properties of limited natural mineral deposits, species of plants, and the like. Oh, and there’s talk that we’ve lost some of the knowledge around some of the early big rockets used get us in orbit and around the moon. But in all cases, what we’re missing is specific historic techniques. We can produce dyes in any color we like, make incendiaries of every description, send rockets into orbit, and so on. We just can’t do them exactly as they did in the past.

Answer: Well, let’s think about it for a bit.What kind of technologies have been invented in the last century?We have things like radar, and microwave, and the internet, and satellites and computer chips, and nuclear power, and canned food, and drones, and aviation technology, and GPS, and infant formula, and indexing of websites for search engines, and bar codes, and touch screens, and vaccines, and windpower, and the accelerometer, and fire resistant clothing, and aerodynamic trucks, airbags, miniature cameras that fit in a webcam or cellphone, weather forecasting, and submarines, cellular technologWell, let’s think about it for a bit.What kind of technologies have been invented in the last century?We have things like radar, and microwave, and the internet, and satellites and computer chips, and nuclear power, and canned food, and drones, and aviation technology, and GPS, and infant formula, and indexing of websites for search engines, and bar codes, and touch screens, and vaccines, and windpower, and the accelerometer, and fire resistant clothing, and aerodynamic trucks, airbags, miniature cameras that fit in a webcam or cellphone, weather forecasting, and submarines, cellular technology and networks, RAM memory, hard disk drives, liquid-crystal displays, lithium batteries, so on.But all that kind of stuff was developed by having governments getting involved, funding research and science and so on.Which, as we all know, is a really inefficient method, it pretty much doesn’t work.Instead of this inefficient method that clearly doesn’t work, of having governments take part in research and development, we now have a much better strategy for innovation:Random guys in their garage!As we all know, that’s where all the true innovation comes from, random middle class dudes, who have ideas, and then do a startup in their garage.Either that, or huge corporations who invest in ways to extend their patents.So now, we have much more groundbreaking innovation.We have things like Amazon, who patented and made a fortune off one-click buying, the truly revolutionary idea of not making people click more than needed.Do you really think that government could have ever come up with a brilliant idea like that, huh?

Answer: Field artillery seems to have become some what common from the 1420s onward.The Dukes of Burgundy for example had hundreds of pieces which can only be described as primarily anti-personal. They commonly shot round stones the size of apples, pears and tennisballs as contemporaries put it. Oversized guns firing 30mm lead shot were also in use. They were more often than not breechloaders which could fire quite fast albeit at somewhat lower power than later guns.At theField artillery seems to have become some what common from the 1420s onward.The Dukes of Burgundy for example had hundreds of pieces which can only be described as primarily anti-personal. They commonly shot round stones the size of apples, pears and tennisballs as contemporaries put it. Oversized guns firing 30mm lead shot were also in use. They were more often than not breechloaders which could fire quite fast albeit at somewhat lower power than later guns.At theThey were used on the field from time to time but usually because they were part of the siege train. For example at the siege of Neuss Charles the Bold had plenty of artillery (several hundred pieces) and they were used to bombard the camp of the relieving army.Below are some sections from…Other than that the Wars of the Roses included a small number of artillery although not always deployed to the best effect.The early 16th century would likewise see quite some artillery fielded. TheIt should be said that towards the end of the 15th and beginning of the 16th century there was a move towards fewer and more powerful cannons and as such it seems the total number of artillery dropped considerably.I have to admit that between the middle of the Italian Wars and the beginning of the Dutch revolt there’s something of a gap in my knowledge of wars. It might well be that the conflict between those two points involved fewer cannons, the French wars of Religion almost certainly did.The almost mythical (re)invention of light field artillery gets attributed to basically any commander who operated in the late 16th and early 17th century. Being the chauvinist that I am I might as well credit Maurice of Nassau with it. He introduced light 3, 6 and 12 pdr guns with the 3 pdr weighing only 300 lbs which meant they could be manhandled easily.A field army of 1622 counted 15 infantry regiments and 6x 12-pdrs, 18x 24- pdrs and 50x small drakes. This preponderance of 24-pdrs and small drakes continued throughout this period, the former often with equal numbers of traditional and short-barrelled pieces (24-pdr drakes). - Dutch Armies of the 80 years war Bouko de GrootIn sum artillery did get used throughout the period but there might have been a reduction in the overal number during parts of the 16th century when fast campaigns without sieges were fought.

Answer: What’s interesting about this is that Leonardo Da Vinci had ideas for many of the mechanical technologies that were developed in the 20th century, in the 15th century (late 1400s), but he was unable to successfully make any of them. He had a very forward-thinking imagination about what was possible, but what he lacked in making his ideas become practical reality was knowledge. The Industrial Revolution wouldn’t happen for another 300 years.How society comes to support the development of knowledge is complex. It’s not a straightforward matter, because that effort occurs in a social, I’d almostWhat’s interesting about this is that Leonardo Da Vinci had ideas for many of the mechanical technologies that were developed in the 20th century, in the 15th century (late 1400s), but he was unable to successfully make any of them. He had a very forward-thinking imagination about what was possible, but what he lacked in making his ideas become practical reality was knowledge. The Industrial Revolution wouldn’t happen for another 300 years.How society comes to support the development of knowledge is complex. It’s not a straightforward matter, because that effort occurs in a social, I’d almost say anthropological context. I feel I can roughly say that the conditions in society need to be right before it can happen, but I’m not clear on what those conditions are. I can say that comfort with exploration and experimentation needs to exist, where people are not averse to taking risks, financial and otherwise, for the sake of gaining new knowledge.A point Richard Feynman made is that you also need a system of wealth accumulation; an economy, and a financial system. For that, you need some system of property rights, which had to be invented.The very notion of invention had to be invented, as well.For a more detailed history on this, I’ve thought James Burke did a great job creating an engaging, and fascinating history of how scientific and engineering knowledge developed in the West, in two series he created,There were many important points he made in these series, but some of them were that the critical inventions and knowledge that were developed came about because of other knowledge that came before them; that certain historical, philosophical, and social events contributed to the fostering of those inventions and ideas; and how that knowledge changed how people thought about, and perceived the world. It changed people’s thinking about what could be made, and why they’d want to make it, as well.Another good source on this is the book,
name: Valerio Cietto
question: https://www.quora.com/Where-does-the-most-advanced-technology-or-knowledge-come-out-the-university-or-company

Answer: Will learning geography in school become redundant due to GPS and other advancing technologies?If your primary school education was so deficient that you think GPS can make geography redundant, your school severely failed in its duty, and I fear to speculate what *else* you’re not informed about.A *proper* geography class discusses the *effects* of geography on things like climate and weather, history, and social policy. For example, explaining why there are often desert or dry lands east of a mountain range, or the impact of the existence of the English Channel on the way World War II playedWill learning geography in school become redundant due to GPS and other advancing technologies?If your primary school education was so deficient that you think GPS can make geography redundant, your school severely failed in its duty, and I fear to speculate what *else* you’re not informed about.A *proper* geography class discusses the *effects* of geography on things like climate and weather, history, and social policy. For example, explaining why there are often desert or dry lands east of a mountain range, or the impact of the existence of the English Channel on the way World War II played out (specifically the Battle of Britain in particular), or what threats rising sea level poses and what society should do about it.None of which has anything to do with GPS.
